description: Erection of a 2-storey side extension and single storey rear extension ; demolition and enlargement of front steps towards street to form side access to lower ground level, new front cast iron spearhead railing,  new paved lightwell with iron grille and garden terraced planting and landscaping and construction of bin storage with green roof and associated external refurbishment works.
application_type_full: Householder planning & demolition in a conservation area
decision_conditions: <p><span id="docs-internal-guid-e3ccb059-7fff-5abd-c4d1-3c3f2ea22e6f"><span style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; font-variant-position: normal; font-variant-emoji: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;">The proposed development, by reason of its excessive scale, design and location in a tight, heavily constrained setting, would result in an overbearing impact, increased sense of enclosure and loss of outlook to adjoining residential properties to the detriment of their living conditions. As such, the proposal would give rise to unacceptable harm to residential amenity, contrary to Policy LP2 of the Hackney Local Plan 2033, Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021, and the Residential Extensions and Alterations SPD (2009).</span></span></p>

<p><span id="docs-internal-guid-fd823352-7fff-a93e-3c67-0b4622bc5a7f"><span style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; font-variant-position: normal; font-variant-emoji: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;">The proposed development, by reason of its extensive glazing and proximity to neighbouring habitable windows at 104 and 106 De Beauvoir Road, would result in an unacceptable loss of privacy and increased perception of overlooking, leading to intrusive views and a harmful reduction in the private enjoyment of those spaces. The proposal would therefore result in a significant adverse impact on the amenity of neighbouring occupiers, contrary to Policy LP2 of the Hackney Local Plan 2033, Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021, and the Residential Extensions and Alterations SPD (2009).</span></span></p>

<p><span id="docs-internal-guid-60b701b7-7fff-e938-2348-6fd0aa252843"><span style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; background-color: transparent; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-variant-alternates: normal; font-variant-position: normal; font-variant-emoji: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space-collapse: preserve;">The proposed development, by reason of its excessive scale, bulk, and unsympathetic design within a constrained plot, would appear as a visually dominant and incongruous addition that would disrupt the original proportions and architectural uniformity of the locally listed terrace, failing to preserve or enhance the character and appearance of the site and wider De Beauvoir Conservation Area. The proposed development would be contrary to Policies D3 (Optimising site capacity through the design-led approach) and HC1 (Heritage conservation) of the London Plan 2021; Policies LP1 (Design Quality and Local Character), LP3 (Designated Heritage Assets), and LP4 (Non-Designated Heritage Assets) of the Hackney Local Plan 2033; the De Beauvoir Conservation Area Appraisal; and the guidance contained in the Residential Extensions and Alterations SPD (2009).</span></span></p>
